Honestly, I hate to discuss this, since I am sure that the GG's out there, ignorant of the law as they tend to be, have no idea that in this country, you can build as many guns as you wish. There is no requirement to put serial numbers or any other markings on them. The only real restriction is that the gun you build may not be an automatic weapon or an assault weapon (at least until the AWB sunsets). You can even sell them, as long as you are not building them specifically to be sold. Of course, considering these are guns with no markings, it would be a nightmare to try to enforce that.
 
 There is a growing group of people doing this, there are even several yahoo groups devoted to the subject. Most of them are biulding kit guns. They buy demilled kits (kits with all the parts included except the reciever, which is the part that is the actual "gun" by legal standards) then they build new recievers for them. 
 
 Of course, the gun kits that are most commonly available are military weapons being cycled out. Some of the more popular I have seen are the 1919, a belt fed squad support class machine gun. Guys are building semi auto versions of these (though from some of the message posting I have seen from some of these guys, there is nothing "semi" about a lot of hte guns being built). The AMD-63 and AMD-65 (short barreled versions of the AK-47 which are illegal to import into the US as guns, but fine to import as kits and re-build here), Uzis seem to be popular builds, as do Stens (A cheap and easy to build SMG). There also seems to be a real market for Druganov sniper rifles.
 
 Personally, I like to build 1911's (my favorite pistol), though I have also built a few Sig 228 copies, a browning high power, a couple of handguns of my own design, I have also built a 1919 (semi for me folks, I already have enough full auto stuff, really don't need to go to jail), a couple af AMD-63's (fun gun to play with), and a couple of .50 caliber rifles (semi-auto, not the bolt action that is generally available to the public). there are others (MAC's, etc...) but the ones listed were some of my more difficult builds.
 
 I don't think there were a whole lot of folks building their own weapons prior to the current gun control legislation, today, though, it seems to be a growing hobby. So, from a practicale standpoint, the current set of gun control laws have had no verifiable effect on crime, but they have helped spawn the construction of tens of thousands, if not hundreds of thousands, of completley undocumented, untraceable, military weapons.
 
 WAY TO GO, ANTI GUNNERS. Another 10 years of this, and we will have created enough undocumented weapons for everybody in the country to have one.
